posts.name: Silvana Edel
posts.cooked: Is there any way to practically eliminate spin up time on these shooters? We’ve had this issue for a few years now, and I feel like the best teams, just, don’t. What are they doing that we don’t see. Seems like it should be relatively simple, because it feels like we’re the outliers here.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: Decrease moment of inertia, which is often done by decreasing weight.
You can have them spin at a set rate during the match. When you go to shoot you can fully rev then up and it should take less time.

posts.name: Liu
posts.cooked: I would be careful if you choose this option since it can change the shot more than you might anticipate since there is a different amount of power that is transferred into the notes.

posts.name: David Powers
posts.cooked:
We’re doing a few things to mitigate this. Here’s a quick list of the things we implemented to decrease the time to shoot to what it is shown below.

Decrease the weight of the flywheel

Gear it so you have some headroom to apply more power during spinup

Use some clever automation control, we’ve got it set so if it has a note on our side of the field, the shooter spins up to 75% power, which is the bulk of the delay of our spinup. You can simplify this and throw a simple beam break sensor in the system and when you have a note it starts spinning the system up.

Decrease friction in the system, this one is sometimes overlooked but make sure your shafts are straight and shooter wheels are balanced, replace the bearings decently often, make sure belt tension and gear mesh are properly spaced, etc

These are just a few things we’ve tried to implement that have helped decrease the amount of time from acquisition to shooting the game piece.

posts.name: Silvana Edel
posts.cooked: This ends up taking up a lot of battery… I know that a 775 pro doesn’t take much power, but it’s more than none, and when we nearly begin browning out by the end of the match, that gets dangerous…

posts.name: Nate
posts.cooked:
If this is the case I would question if you have an electrical issue, or need to optimise your power draw.

What drive system are you using currently? And are all the other motors 775 pros?
Maybe you can play around with the values more. Or you can have your driver/operator start revving early so when you get there the shooter is good to go.

posts.name: Andrew Schreiber
posts.cooked:
To quote a very famous scientist…

Inertia is a property of matter

Spin up time is a function of the energy you are putting into a system, the mass of that system, and losses in that system. Adjust those (increase energy in, decrease losses, decrease mass) and you will decrease the spin up time.  Keep in mind that adjusting those things can have other impacts on the system’s performance and controllabillity.

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
I would challenge this notion without seeing data.

Unless there’s a lot of friction in your flywheel, it shouldn’t take much power at all to keep the wheel going at a constant speed (an object in motion stays in motion).

If you look at current draw, you’ll see that there’s a large peak in current when you actually have to accelerate the wheel, versus a very low baseline amount when you just let it spin.

Compare this to the current draw of your drive motors, which are constantly accelerating and turning around, keeping a flywheel spin up should be a drop in the bucket.

All that being said, I think the simplest answer is what others have said, which is train your copilot to rev the flywheel early.

posts.name: John Bottenberg
posts.cooked:
No spin up time here! Or PID for that matter. We just set the shooter and feeder motors to max voltage as soon as the operator presses the button.

https://youtu.be/O_YDGuxREwM?si=CxLOnklZ2Gc6CL51

posts.name: Andrew Schreiber
posts.cooked: We ran like that most of build season but found that we were getting different shots as batteries ran down. Highly suggest even a simple PID on it just to help deal with battery sag. (Not that it matters if you’re going full bore at the start of the match, but… we don’t do that)

posts.name: John Bottenberg
posts.cooked:
PID is incredibly valuable, and it allows teams to fire off accurate shots from very far away.

All that considered, this year our team decided to only really shoot from the location on the field where the effective aperture of the speaker is the largest. The speaker is absolutely gaping wide when you shoot from the subwoofer, and with our setup it is pretty much impossible to miss. Even if the shooter’s effective exit velocity varies by as much as 20%, the shot is still going in. This is true even with almost-destroyed notes, etc.

Rapid fire capability is important this year. With amplified periods only being 10 seconds long, it’s important to minimize the time to get a note into/through/out of the robot and into the speaker.

posts.name: Electra Lucky Norwood
posts.cooked:
Do you have a battery beak to check the health of your batteries?

These other suggestions about electrical issues or optimizing power draw are good, but there’s been multiple times I’ve spoken to teams about power issues and their battery internal resistance was very bad. Even on batteries they just bought because they mistreated them, left them in the cold, had them sit uncharged, etc.

You can have an amazing robot, but bad battery management can make all of it null.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
John_Bottenberg:

PID is incredibly valuable

If properly done.  Unfortunately, it is easy to do PID improperly, especially when your target is a speed rather than a position.  For a shooter wheel, bang-bang or a variant is usually more effective at getting the shooter up to speed quickly.  Bang bang works like the thermostat in your oven or home air conditioner - it’s either on full, or off.  If it’s too slow, give full throttle, if too fast, none (be sure you’re in coast!).  The test and cycle time of the motor controller is usually fast enough to keep you well within your required speed tolerance.
